_exec_summary.SummaryText:
As our LEPC and SEPC are one and the same, we will coordinate our program with the local fire department.  A representative group from the fire department will be requested to be a part of spill exercises and if desired, routine visits to the site to discuss how to respond to a release of TDI.  We have also given local medical service providers information regarding medical treatment for exposure to TDI.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

At this time the facility has been in operation for 5 years.  All of the equipment is still fairly new. We will continue to review our operations as required by our current EH&S management systems and scrutinize our systems as we drive continual improvement through operational efficiency, process training and maintenance.  Since our last RMP submittal, we have more than doubled the number of PM activities related to Isocyanate release prevention.  We have also developed and implemented improvements in our RMP training, across the organization. 


In addition, we will conduct quarterly “Spill drills” with the emergency response team to ensure our preparedness to react to a spill, mitigate the hazards and limit release quantities.

This boundary would include the neighboring business to our south as well as a portion of Endeavor Way Rd.   


4. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Specific Prevention Steps

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  Our management systems for our TDI process address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:

Contractor Awareness
Hot Work Permitting
Monthly Workplace Inspection by members of the JHS&E Team
Safety Information
Hazard Reviews of our Processes
Operating Procedures
Training
Equipment Maintenance Programs
RMP Compliance Audits
Accident/Incident Investigation

In addition, we have an established Isocyanate Control Program that outlines both the hazards of handling Toluene Diisocyanate and the controls that are in place to reduce those hazards.  Controls are in place to reduce exposure to employees, the community, and the environment.

These listed individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems are setup for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention. 

5. Five-year Accident History

The Tanner, Alabama Foam Plant has no history of any uncontrolled releases or spills of TDI.  There are documented incidents on file for minor spills inside of the building including all history since the facility was built. Each was within the enclosed containment area.

6. The Emergency Response Plan

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides essential planning and training to effectively protect workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

ntrols and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.

The methodology used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint as established by the RMP rule was EPA’s RMP Comp.

WORST-CASE Release Scenario:

Catastrophic failure of a truck tanker full of TDI at the unloading site; discharging its entire contents of 45000lbs outside of containment using the ALOHA model.  

The facility used the ALOHA model and guidance contained in the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint for each worst-case release scenario.  
For the worst-case scenario, the maximum average temperature for July being 88.3 degrees and RH 75%, maximum average wind speed of 8.7mph were used (data source weather-us.com)

It is assumed that the maximum temperature the TDI could reach during an unload is 110 degrees F.  The chemical escaped as a liquid from the tank and formed an evaporating puddle. The puddle spread to a diameter of 72 yards.
Max Average Sustained Release Rate: 0.685 pounds/min. The total Amount Released: 31.0 pounds
Note: The chemical escaped as a liquid and formed an evaporating puddle.
The distance to the endpoint concentration of 0.02 mg/L is 753 yards.  
There are no residences within this boundary.  
This boundary does include 11 businesses, Endeavor Way Rd, and a portion of I-65.

ALTERNATIVE Release Scenario:

While off-loading, from a tanker truck, a 2 inch hose ruptures length triggering a release of TDI.  Excess flow valves function to stop the flow, and roughly 10% of the tanker capacity was released into our containment area.  The resulting liquid forms a puddle with a surface area of 306 square feet with a volume of 450 gallons which evaporates to form a toxic cloud that disperses downwind.     
Max Average Sustained Release Rate: 0.0135 pounds/min.  The total Amount Released: 0.53 pounds
The distance to the endpoint concentration of 0.02 mg/L is 102 yards.  
There are no residences wit

Tanner, Alabama Foam Plant is to produce polyurethane foam seat cushions for the automotive industry.  The foam is made by high pressure mixing of chemicals as they are poured into a mold that is attached by carrier to a continuously moving line.  The mold then moves through a curing oven.  Upon exiting the oven, the foam pads are removed from the mold, vacuum or mechanically crushed, trimmed, and prepared for shipment to customers.

Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), which is regulated by EPA's risk management program rule, is one of the reactants required to manufacture polyurethane foam.  TDI is received at the plant by tanker truck, and is stored in 2 tanks located in the contained bulk storage tank room.  The TDI is then transferred to the process utilizing a computer-controlled system.

Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, management personnel, and contractors.  

To be conservative, the facility has calculated the maximum possible inventory of TDI which could be onsite in order to determine the maximum intended inventory.  This quantity is based on assuming TDI is stored in all of the following vessels:

Name	 Size of container	Container volume (-10%) (Theoretical)	Location	Actual Stored - lbs.	Actual Stored - Gallons
Tank 1	10,750	9,675 gal.	Tank Farm	102,000 lbs.	10,000 gal.
Tank 2	10,750	9,675 gal.	Tank Farm	102,000 lbs.	10,000 gal.
Surge Tank 1	 40 gal.	36 gal.	Process area	306 lbs.	30 gal.
Surge Tank 2	40 gal.	36 gal.	Process area	306 lbs.	30 gal.

The maximum amount of TDI that can be stored at this facility is:
•	204,612 lbs.-facility vessels
•	45,000 lbs. Full tanker truck - this is temporary during off loading into the bulk storage Tanks 1 or 2
 

3. Off-site Consequence Analysis Scenarios

EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release and alternative release scenarios for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative co

WOODBRIDGE AL, LP RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

This document contains a description of the RMP program at Woodbridge AL, LP, Tanner, AL  facility.  The following sections describe in detail the facilities approach in developing the RMP program and the following:

1. Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies

The Tanner, Alabama Foam Plant, as part of the Woodbridge group of companies, believes the health & safety of its employees and the protection of the natural environment, is of the utmost concern in the operation of its business.  We are committed to operating & maintaining all of our processes in a safe & responsible manner.

It is our policy to:

Comply with all applicable laws, regulations, and standards.
Review and assess our operations for the purpose of making health, safety, & environmental improvements.

Our complete Health, Safety, & Environmental policy statement, signed by our plant manager, is posted in the lobby of our facility.

We use a combination of prevention programs and emergency response planning, which are described later in this document, to help ensure the safety of our employees, the public, and to ensure protection of the environment.  Our Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program.  To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our Plant Manager has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to a staff member with the background, training, and experience necessary to manage the program.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Plant Manager, is responsible for coordinating the development, implementation and integration of the RMP elements as is required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.
